ray.rage.rendersystem.states

Interface ZBufferState

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Disposable, RenderState
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    GL4ZBufferState

    public interface ZBufferState
extends RenderState
    A z-buffer state has information about settings related to depth testing.

    Depth testing is a non-programmable stage that processes the output fragment of a fragment shader program (i.e. a "candidate pixel") to determine how "close" to the viewer each one is. When it's determined that a new fragment is "closer" to the viewer than the previously stored fragment at the same position, the new value is used to overwrite the old one. Otherwise, the new one is discarded because it's considered to be occluded (assuming no transparency).

    Author:
    Raymond L. Rivera

      • setTestEnabled

        void setTestEnabled(boolean enabled)
        Sets whether depth-testing should be performed on every fragment or not.

        This should not be confused with enabling/disabling render-state itself, which would determine whether this gets applied or not. Enabling/Disabling z-buffer testing simply determines whether fragments should or should not be tested at all.

        For example, disabling the render-state would mean that subsequent fragments will be processed using the last z-state to have been applied, whereas disabling depth-testing itself will update overwrite the previous state.

        Parameters:
        enabled -

      • hasTestEnabled

        boolean hasTestEnabled()
        Gets whether depth-testing is being performed or not.
        Returns:
        true if depth-testing is being performed. Otherwise false.
        See Also:
        setTestEnabled(boolean)

      • setWritable

        void setWritable(boolean writable)
        Sets whether the depth-buffer can be written to or not.
        Parameters:
        writable - true if the buffer can be written to. Otherwise false.

      • isWritable

        boolean isWritable()
        Gets whether the depth buffer can have new values written to it or not.
        Returns:
        true if the buffer can be written to. Otherwise false.
